summary: Block Access to North Korea Act of 2016 or BANK Act of 2016 This bill requires the President to impose sanctions pursuant to the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, with specified waiver authority, against a person that continues to knowingly and directly provide specialized financial messaging services to, or to knowingly enable or facilitate access to such messaging services for:   the Central Bank of the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea),  a financial institution that facilitates any transaction or provides significant financial services for nuclear development or proliferation on North Korea's behalf, or  a person identified on the list of specially designated nationals and blocked persons maintained by the Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control for assisting North Korea's nuclear development or proliferation efforts.
predicted_summary: North Korea Block Access Act This bill directs the President to impose sanctions against a person or entity that: provides specialized financial messaging services (or facilitates the direct or indirect provision of such services) to, or facilitates the access of any person to, the North Korean government, its agents or their affiliates, or other entities or persons engaged in activities that support North Korean proliferation or activities to develop nuclear weapons or ballistic missiles. The President may waive such sanctions if in the national interest of the United States. The bill includes in the list of sanctioned persons a person that provides or has provided such messaging services to North Korea or to North Korean officials or other persons or entities or North Korean entities.

summary: Social Security Protection Act of 2011 - Makes it out of order in the Senate or the House of Representatives to consider any legislation that: (1) increases the retirement age or the early retirement age for individuals receiving benefits under title II (Old Age, Survivors, and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act on or after the enactment of this Act; (2) reduces cost-of-living increases for them; (3) reduces benefit payment amounts for them; or (4) creates private retirement accounts for any of the OSADI benefits they receive.
predicted_summary: Social Security Protection Act of 2011 - Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to require the Commissioner of Social Security to report to Congress annually on the status of the OASDI program, including both surplus and deficit amounts, and the impact of any proposed changes to such program on the lives of beneficiaries, families, and beneficiaries.Social Security Reform Act of 2013 - Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to increase the payroll tax rate for employers and employees subject to the payroll taxes for Social Security benefits. Amends the Internal Revenue Code to impose a tax on employers equal of .25 percent of the amount paid in an taxable year for social security benefits.Amends the Social Security Act of 1937 to raise the age for entitlement to Social Security disability benefits from age 65 to 68. Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social security Act of 1974 to: (1) eliminate the cap on benefits payable to individuals who are disabled before age 65; (2) increase the average age for retirement benefits to 67; and (3) require an increase in the retirement age of any individual who attains age 65 before the end of his or her career, if the average retirement age is not raised.Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act to make it out of order in the Senate or the House of Representatives to consider any legislation that: (1) increases the retirement age or the early retirement age (age) for individuals receiving benefits under OASDI title II; or (2) reduces the cost-of-living adjustment (COLA) for such beneficiaries.Amends title II (Old Age, Survivors and Disability Insurance) (OASDI) of the Social Security Act (SSA) to: (1) reduce cost-of-living increases for individuals receiving OASDI benefits on or after the date of enactment of this Act; (2) reduce benefit payment amounts for such individuals; (3) create private retirement accounts for them; and (4) require the transfer of Social Security surplus funds to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund to pay interest on such accounts. Authorizes the waiver or suspension of the requirements in the Senate and House only by a rule or order proposing only to waive or suspend the application of such requirements in a joint resolution.Amends the Rules of the House of Representatives to prohibit a motion to suspend the application of a joint resolution of disapproval to a proposed amendment to a bill that is introduced in the House.

summary: Gold King Mine Spill Accountability Act of 2016 This bill requires the Department of Justice (DOJ) to appoint a special investigator to investigate: (1) who was at fault for the discharge of contaminated water from the Gold King Mine north of Silverton, Colorado, into Cement Creek; (2) which individuals were responsible for the decisions that led to the spill; and (3) what downstream environmental effects were caused by the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) actions, or inactions, after the spill.  The bill: (1) entitles individuals to receive compensation for a claim filed, or civil action brought, under the Federal Tort Claims Act relating to an injury resulting from the spill, and (2) establishes within the EPA the Office of Gold King Mine Spill Claims for processing claims of allowable damages resulting from the spill. The EPA may provide compensation for a claim in an amount greater than $25,000 without the prior approval of DOJ. The EPA must fund the implementation of the long-term monitoring program developed by the Long-Term Impact Review Team of New Mexico, for the water quality of the Animas and San Juan Rivers. The EPA may not finalize or work on any rules (including those not related to the spill) until all claims have been paid, except rules that are necessary to address an imminent threat to public health or safety, or other emergency.
predicted_summary: Gold King Mine Spill Accountability Act of 2016 This bill requires the Department of Justice (DOJ) to appoint a special investigator to conduct an investigation to determine: (1) who was at fault for the spill, which individuals were responsible for the decisions that led to the spill and what downstream environmental effects were caused by the actions of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), or the EPA's failure to take action; and (2) what actions the EPA must take to prevent a similar spill in the future. The investigator must be compensated for investigation expenses.Authorizes the special investigator to: (1) appoint and fix the pay of additional personnel; (2) request Federal agency personnel to assist; and (3) secure information necessary to carry out this Act.Requires the special investigator (in this case, the Attorney General) to issue a subpoena to the person to whom the subpoena is directed to testify or produce evidence. Authorizes a U.S. District Court to grant an order requiring a person to appear before the Special investigator.Requires: (1) the special investigator to report to Congress on the results of the investigation and a report on the investigator's conflict of interest; and (2) the Comptroller General to report with respect to whether the investigator had any conflicts of interest and whether the findings are based on substantiated scientific evidence.Authorizes the Administrator to provide compensation for a claim under this Act in an amount greater than $25,000 without prior written approval of the Attorney General (or a designee), as the Administrator, without the federal tort claims limitation.Establishes within the Environmental Protection Agency an office of gold king mine spill claims. Directs the office to receive, process, and pay claims. Sets forth provisions regarding allowable damages and administrative costs.Provides for the payment of claims for damages to: (1) tribal or non-federal land; (2) property of a person injured in the incident to the extent that the person is not a tribal member; (3) property of the United States; and (4) other property of an injured person in the course of the injury or in the same area.Provides compensation for injuries resulting from the gold king mine spill in the United States on September 25, 2008, including any injury for which compensation may be provided under the Federal Employees Compensation Act.Requires the Secretary of the Interior to establish a program to respond to a gold mine spill in accordance with the laws of the jurisdiction in which the spill occurred. (Under current law, the Secretary must: (1) establish a response program to address a mine spill within a specified area; and (2) notify the public of the presence of a hazardous substance.) Sets forth provisions regarding the liability of federal contractors and subcontractors under state laws.Long-Term Monitoring Program Implementation Act of 2016 This bill requires the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to fund the implementation of a long-term monitoring program to improve water quality in the San Juan and Santa Fe River watersheds in New Mexico. The program must: provide full disclosure to the public of water quality and sediment data; enable clear and meaningful comparison between those data and all relevant water quality standards; and meet certain other conditions the EPA may require to administer the program. The EPA may not finalize a rule to implement this bill until all claims processed under this bill have been paid in full. This bill also prohibits the EPA from implementing any rule that the EPA determines is necessary to address an imminent threat to public health or safety or any emergency.3 million gallons of contaminated water from the gold king mine north of silverton, colorado, into creek cement that occurred while contractors of the Environmental Protection Agency were conducting an investigation of the mine.

summary:
Rural Broadband Access Enhancement Act - Amends the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 to redefine "eligible rural community."

Permits a loan or loan guarantee applicant in an area where 40% of the residents are without broadband access to qualify with a 10% loan equity position.

Provides for: (1) paperwork reduction; and (2) program outreach to underserved areas.

Prohibits loan or loan guarantees for new broadband service in communities with three or more service providers.

Provides that for each fiscal year: (1) not more than 10% of program funds shall be available to providers with more than 10% of national subscriber lines; and (2) 40% of program funds shall be available to providers with between 2%-10% of national subscriber lines.

Revises the amortization period from the life of the asset to 35 years.

Requires an annual broadband program report to Congress.
predicted_summary: Rural broadband access enhancement Act - Amends the Rural Electrification Act of 1936 to include as an eligible rural community any community: (1) not included within the urbanized area contiguous or adjacent to a city, town, borough, or village with a population of more than 20,000; (2) not in the average median household income of which is not more than 80% of the national average household income; and (3) not within the special rural area.Prohibits the Secretary from approving an application to serve: (1) an area in which at least 40% of the population does not have access to broadband service; or (2) any other area if the value of the applicant's assets does not equal at least 10% of the principal amount of the loan which is the subject of the application, or 15% of the Principal Amount of the Loan.Directs the Secretary to conduct outreach to inform the population of areas in which there is no or limited access to broadband service of the program. Prohibits the Administrator of the Rural Electrification Administration (REA) from approving an application for a loan or loan guarantee for new broadband service in a rural community in which three or more entities provide service. Eliminates: (1) the eligibility of a rural area for participation in such program based upon the number of subscribers, and (2) the broadband service limitation for eligible entities.Prohibits more than ten percent of the amounts made available for each fiscal year from being used to provide loans or loan guarantees to entities with more than five percent of telephone subscriber lines installed in the aggregate in the States.Directs the Secretary to report annually to Congress on the status of the program. Includes among the report's contents: the identity of the communities served by those communities; the type of services offered by applicants and recipients; the speed of the broadband service offered by the applicants; and the outreach efforts conducted by the Secretary.

summary:
Wounded Warrior Transition Assistance Act of 2009 - Directs the Secretary of each military department to provide each reserve member of that department who is being evaluated for separation or retirement for disability, or for placement on the temporary disability retired list or inactive status list, the option to remain on active duty during such evaluation in order to continue to receive military pay and allowances, until the member is: (1) cleared to return to duty; or (2) separated, retired, or placed on the temporary disability retired or inactive status list.

Requires each Secretary to retain on active duty (for pay and allowances purposes) a reserve member who incurs an injury or illness while on active duty, is being discharged or separated from the Armed Forces, or is being released from active duty, and is not being evaluated in connection with such discharge, separation, or release, until the member is: (1) retired or placed on the temporary disability retired or inactive status list; or (2) determined ineligible for such care or benefits based solely upon the injury or illness.

Requires military human resources commands to return to active duty during their evaluation period reserve members who request such option.

Encourages the use of local residences by reserve members during such transition periods.

Authorizes the use of Defense Health Program funds for reserve members who become ill or injured while on active duty and separate as a result of such illness or injury.

Provides for the assignment of Judge Advocate General personnel to assist members of the Armed Forces (members) in connection with the medical discharge process and disability evaluations.

Expresses support for access of veterans service organizations to military facilities to provide counseling and services to members.
predicted_summary: Wounded Warrior Transition Assistance Act of 2009 - Requires the Secretary of a military department to give an individual who is being evaluated by a physical evaluation board for separation or retirement for disability or for placement on the temporary disability retired list or inactive status list the option to remain on active duty in order to continue to receive pay and allowances during such process.Requires the Secretary of a military department to retain a member on active duty who incurs an injury or illness while on duty and who is being discharged or separated or released from active duty, but who is not being evaluated by a physical evaluation board for purposes of such discharge, separation, or release in order to continue to receive pay and allowances until such time as the member: (1) is retired or placed on the temporary disability retired list or inactive status list; or (2) is determined not to be eligible for such care or benefits based solely upon such injury or Illness. Allows such member to elect to be discharged, separated, or released, as applicable.Requires: (1) the applicable human resources command to return to active duty for such purposes any member who requests retention; and (2) such return shall be for the purpose of receiving medical evaluation, treatment, care, and benefits.Requires members of reserve components of the Armed Forces to reside at such locations at the time they are called to active duty, unless otherwise required by law. Allows such members to move from one location to another without incurring the same housing requirements. Allows members to live at their permanent place of residence, however, if they are otherwise qualified to do so.Makes funds in the defense health program available, subject to appropriations, for support programs for any member of a reserve component who becomes ill or injured while on active duty and separates from active duty as a result of the illness or injury.Requires the Office of the Secretary of Defense for Health Affairs to coordinate with reserve components, including the National Guard, in determining the budget requirements of such reserve components for support programs. Directs each military department Secretary to ensure that the number of members of the judge advocate general's corps under its jurisdiction who are dedicated to providing legal assistance to members in connection with such discharge is adequate to meet the needs of all members involved in the discharge process.Requires the Secretary of a military department to ensure that each member under such department who is undergoing medical discharge receives appropriate legal assistance on all legal matters relating to such discharge. Directs each department Secretary to: (1) ensure that the judge advocate general's corps under the jurisdiction of such Secretary has the capacity to provide legal assistance to members who are undergoing disability evaluation by the Department of Veterans Affairs in connection with such disability evaluation; and (2) maintain and assign to each member the appropriate personnel who will assist with such evaluation.Requires the Secretary of each military department to ensure that each member of the Armed Forces undergoing a disability evaluation by the Department of Veterans Affairs receives appropriate legal assistance on all legal matters relating to such evaluation.Expresses the sense of Congress that: (1) each commander of a military installation should ensure the use of space and equipment at such installations by representatives of veterans service organizations (currently, only the Secretary of Veterans Affairs may authorize such use of facilities at military installations); (2) each commander should endeavor to provide private space to access such organizations for counseling and services; and (3) the Secretary should widely disseminate information regarding the existence and availability of the wounded warrior resource center.The wounded warrior center should provide legal assistance to members and dependents of the Armed Forces who are injured or killed while on active duty or inactive duty during a period of war or military training.
